property.value: U.S. Marines sharing a meal with their interpreter, Afghanistan

note.text: Interpreting is demanding work, and interpreters need breaks in order to keep providing high-quality interpretations. Rotate interpreters, when possible, so you do not become over-dependent on someone specific or burn them out. You will lose your ability to communicate clearly if your interpreter is tired or hungry.

property.name: mediadisplayblurb
property.value: U.S. Army officers having dinner with Iraqi army officers and interpreters, Iraq

note.text: When operationally possible, allow your interpreter to take a break whenever you take one.

Remember that the interpreter is working, not socializing, at social events. Let your interpreter break to eat if they are working to translate a conversation over a meal. This means that the interpreted conversation will pause for a short period.

property.name: mediadisplayblurb
property.value: Providing medical information with the help of an interpreter, Haiti

note.text: It is recommended that more than one interpreter be used on a long assignment, if possible. Because interpreting can be exhausting, the quality of interpreters' work begins to decline after about four hours of active interpreting in a day. Having more than one interpreter will allow rotation, which helps ensure superior work.
